trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery: Frequently asked questions
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery: Frequently asked questions

trans-unit.source: This article discusses popular questions about using Azure Site Recovery.
trans-unit.target: This article discusses popular questions about using Azure Site Recovery.

trans-unit.source: This article includes frequently asked questions about Azure Site Recovery.
trans-unit.target: This article includes frequently asked questions about Azure Site Recovery.

trans-unit.source: For an introduction to Site Recovery and related deployment scenarios, read the <linkText>Site Recovery Overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an introduction to Site Recovery and related deployment scenarios, read the <linkText>Site Recovery Overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you have other questions after reading this article, you can post them on the <linkText>Azure Recovery Services Forum</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you have other questions after reading this article, you can post them on the <linkText>Azure Recovery Services Forum</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Yes, ASR is secure.
trans-unit.target: Yes, ASR is secure.

trans-unit.source: It neither intercepts your application data nor has any information about what is running inside your virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: It neither intercepts your application data nor has any information about what is running inside your virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: No Internet connectivity is needed, either from the Hyper-V hosts or the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: No Internet connectivity is needed, either from the Hyper-V hosts or the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Since replication is between your own enterprise and service provider sites, no application data is sent to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Since replication is between your own enterprise and service provider sites, no application data is sent to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Only metadata, such as VM or cloud names, that is needed to orchestrate failover, is sent to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Only metadata, such as VM or cloud names, that is needed to orchestrate failover, is sent to Azure.

trans-unit.source: ASR does not have the ability to intercept your application data, and that data always remains on-premises.
trans-unit.target: ASR does not have the ability to intercept your application data, and that data always remains on-premises.

trans-unit.source: ASR is ISO 27001:2005-certified, and is in the process of completing its HIPAA, DPA, and FedRAMP JAB assessments.
trans-unit.target: ASR is ISO 27001:2005-certified, and is in the process of completing its HIPAA, DPA, and FedRAMP JAB assessments.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: When you create a Site Recovery vault in a region of your choice, we ensure that all metadata that we need to enable and orchestrate your disaster recovery setup remains within that region's geographic boundary.
trans-unit.target: When you create a Site Recovery vault in a region of your choice, we ensure that all metadata that we need to enable and orchestrate your disaster recovery setup remains within that region's geographic boundary.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: ASR workflows can be automated using Rest API, PowerShell, or Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: ASR workflows can be automated using Rest API, PowerShell, or Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can find more details in the blog post titled <linkText>Introducing PowerShell support for Azure Site Recovery</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can find more details in the blog post titled <linkText>Introducing PowerShell support for Azure Site Recovery</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Between on-premises to Azure & between on-premises replication supports encryption in transit for Hyper-V & VMM protection scenarios. Hyper-V & VMM protection to Azure supports encryption at rest as well. Refer this article for more information.
trans-unit.target: Between on-premises to Azure & between on-premises replication supports encryption in transit for Hyper-V & VMM protection scenarios. Hyper-V & VMM protection to Azure supports encryption at rest as well. Refer this article for more information.

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V & VMM scenarios: No, Hyper-V virtual machine replication using Host based replication can only be configured for 30 secs, 5 mins and 15 mins
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V & VMM scenarios: No, Hyper-V virtual machine replication using Host based replication can only be configured for 30 secs, 5 mins and 15 mins

trans-unit.source: VMware/Physical scenario: This isn't applicable for in-guest based replication because technology uses continuous data protection.
trans-unit.target: VMware/Physical scenario: This isn't applicable for in-guest based replication because technology uses continuous data protection.

trans-unit.source: This isn't supported.
trans-unit.target: This isn't supported.

trans-unit.source: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Exclude disk from replication</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Exclude disk from replication</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V & VMM scenarios supports dynamic disks. VMware virtual machine or Physical machine scenarios doesn't support dynamic disk. Send us your feedback through Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum.
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V & VMM scenarios supports dynamic disks. VMware virtual machine or Physical machine scenarios doesn't support dynamic disk. Send us your feedback through Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Standard Geo-redundant storage</linkText><title></title> is supported.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Standard Geo-redundant storage</linkText><title></title> is supported.

trans-unit.source: [Premium Storage Account]((../storage/storage-premium-storage-preview-portal/) is supported only for <linkText>VMware virtual machine or Physical machine scenarios</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: [Premium Storage Account]((../storage/storage-premium-storage-preview-portal/) is supported only for <linkText>VMware virtual machine or Physical machine scenarios</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Support for Standard locally redundant storage is in backlogs, send us your feedback through <linkText>Support for locally redundant storage support</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Support for Standard locally redundant storage is in backlogs, send us your feedback through <linkText>Support for locally redundant storage support</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This isn't supported.
trans-unit.target: This isn't supported.

trans-unit.source: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Support for extending replication</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Support for extending replication</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This isn't supported.
trans-unit.target: This isn't supported.

trans-unit.source: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Support for offline replication</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Send us your feedback through <linkText>Azure Site Recovery Feedback Forum - Support for offline replication</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 can be used when you choose Hyper-V Replica to enable replication and protection between Hyper-V Sites.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 can be used when you choose Hyper-V Replica to enable replication and protection between Hyper-V Sites.

trans-unit.source: The most current list of supported guest operating systems is available in the topic titled <linkText>About Virtual Machines and Guest Operating Systems</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The most current list of supported guest operating systems is available in the topic titled <linkText>About Virtual Machines and Guest Operating Systems</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can't configure Hyper-V runing on a client operating system to replicate virtual machines to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can't configure Hyper-V runing on a client operating system to replicate virtual machines to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Hyper-V Replica is only supported on server operating systems.
trans-unit.target: Hyper-V Replica is only supported on server operating systems.

trans-unit.source: You can replicate your physical client computers to Azure using <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can replicate your physical client computers to Azure using <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Yes, ASR supports replication of generation 2 virtual machines on Hyper-V to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Yes, ASR supports replication of generation 2 virtual machines on Hyper-V to Azure.

trans-unit.source: ASR converts from generation 2 to generation 1 during failover.
trans-unit.target: ASR converts from generation 2 to generation 1 during failover.

trans-unit.source: At failback the machine is converted back to generation 1.
trans-unit.target: At failback the machine is converted back to generation 1.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Read more</linkText><title></title> for further information.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Read more</linkText><title></title> for further information.

trans-unit.source: Yes, ASR supports both dedicated and shared infrastructure models.
trans-unit.target: Yes, ASR supports both dedicated and shared infrastructure models.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: In fact, your tenants do not need access to the ASR portal.
trans-unit.target: In fact, your tenants do not need access to the ASR portal.

trans-unit.source: Only the service provider administrator performs actions on the ASR portal in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Only the service provider administrator performs actions on the ASR portal in Azure.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure's billing relationship remains directly with the service provider.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure's billing relationship remains directly with the service provider.

trans-unit.source: Service providers are responsible for generating specific bills for their tenants.
trans-unit.target: Service providers are responsible for generating specific bills for their tenants.

trans-unit.source: When using a service provider-owned site for DR, application data never goes to Azure.
trans-unit.target: When using a service provider-owned site for DR, application data never goes to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Data is encrypted and replicated directly between the service provider sites.
trans-unit.target: Data is encrypted and replicated directly between the service provider sites.

trans-unit.source: When using Azure as a DR Site, application data is sent to Azure – Data at-rest and in-transit remains encrypted.
trans-unit.target: When using Azure as a DR Site, application data is sent to Azure – Data at-rest and in-transit remains encrypted.

trans-unit.source: You can also use VPN, ExpressRoute, or Public Internet to establish connectivity to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can also use VPN, ExpressRoute, or Public Internet to establish connectivity to Azure.

trans-unit.source: No, ASR is designed as a first-class, public cloud DRaaS solution.
trans-unit.target: No, ASR is designed as a first-class, public cloud DRaaS solution.

trans-unit.source: Data is replicated to a geo-redundant Azure storage account in your own subscription.
trans-unit.target: Data is replicated to a geo-redundant Azure storage account in your own subscription.

trans-unit.source: When you perform a DR drill or an actual failover, ASR automatically creates virtual machines in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: When you perform a DR drill or an actual failover, ASR automatically creates virtual machines in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: We support Azure Pack, Cloud Platform System, and System Center based Hyper 2012 and higher deployments.
trans-unit.target: We support Azure Pack, Cloud Platform System, and System Center based Hyper 2012 and higher deployments.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the ASR and Azure Pack integration, see <linkText>Configure protection for virtual machines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the ASR and Azure Pack integration, see <linkText>Configure protection for virtual machines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Yes, single SCVMM deployments is supported for either scenarios – DR between service provider sites and DR between a service provider site and Azure.
trans-unit.target: Yes, single SCVMM deployments is supported for either scenarios – DR between service provider sites and DR between a service provider site and Azure.

trans-unit.source: Single Azure Pack deployment is also supported when you enable DR between service provider sites, however, ASR Runbook integration is not available for this topology.
trans-unit.target: Single Azure Pack deployment is also supported when you enable DR between service provider sites, however, ASR Runbook integration is not available for this topology.

trans-unit.source: No, it is not mandatory; ASR works over the public Internet as well.
trans-unit.target: No, it is not mandatory; ASR works over the public Internet as well.

trans-unit.source: However, if you have configured site-to-site VPN, you will be able to access the failed over virtual machines in the same manner as before.
trans-unit.target: However, if you have configured site-to-site VPN, you will be able to access the failed over virtual machines in the same manner as before.

trans-unit.source: For more information about networking considerations when enabling Disaster Recovery to Azure, see the <linkText>Networking Infrastructure Setup for Microsoft Azure as a Disaster Recovery Site blog</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about networking considerations when enabling Disaster Recovery to Azure, see the <linkText>Networking Infrastructure Setup for Microsoft Azure as a Disaster Recovery Site blog</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In steady state, we replicate changes to Geo-Redundant Azure Storage and you don’t need to pay any Azure IaaS virtual machine charges (a significant advantage).
trans-unit.target: In steady state, we replicate changes to Geo-Redundant Azure Storage and you don’t need to pay any Azure IaaS virtual machine charges (a significant advantage).

trans-unit.source: When you perform a failover to Azure, ASR automatically creates Azure IaaS virtual machines, after which you are billed for the compute resources that you consume in Azure.
trans-unit.target: When you perform a failover to Azure, ASR automatically creates Azure IaaS virtual machines, after which you are billed for the compute resources that you consume in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can use ASR to protect virtual machines running on the Hyper-V hosts that are not managed by SCVMM.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can use ASR to protect virtual machines running on the Hyper-V hosts that are not managed by SCVMM.

trans-unit.source: When you use ASR to manage the disaster recovery needs of all your branch offices, you get a unified view of all your branch office workloads in one central location.
trans-unit.target: When you use ASR to manage the disaster recovery needs of all your branch offices, you get a unified view of all your branch office workloads in one central location.

trans-unit.source: You also achieve one-click failover and disaster recovery administration of all branches from your head office, without ever going to the branch.
trans-unit.target: You also achieve one-click failover and disaster recovery administration of all branches from your head office, without ever going to the branch.

trans-unit.source: Currently, networking mapping and encryption-at-rest are not supported for branch office disaster recovery.
trans-unit.target: Currently, networking mapping and encryption-at-rest are not supported for branch office disaster recovery.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Support remains the same as it does in our enterprise scenario.
trans-unit.target: Support remains the same as it does in our enterprise scenario.

trans-unit.source: You don't need an agent on the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: You don't need an agent on the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: You need to install the Site Recovery Provider and the Recovery Services Agent on each Hyper-V server running virtual machines you want to protect.
trans-unit.target: You need to install the Site Recovery Provider and the Recovery Services Agent on each Hyper-V server running virtual machines you want to protect.

trans-unit.source: These two components are installed with a single Provider file that can be downloaded during Site Recovery deployment.
trans-unit.target: These two components are installed with a single Provider file that can be downloaded during Site Recovery deployment.

trans-unit.source: No specific setting is required.
trans-unit.target: No specific setting is required.

trans-unit.source: The Provider components on the server communicate over an HTTPS connection to Azure and use the default internet setting on the Hyper-V host server unless otherwise specified.
trans-unit.target: The Provider components on the server communicate over an HTTPS connection to Azure and use the default internet setting on the Hyper-V host server unless otherwise specified.

trans-unit.source: No the server doesn't need to be in a domain
trans-unit.target: No the server doesn't need to be in a domain

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 can be used when using ASR and Hyper-V replication between a Hyper-V sites and Azure.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 can be used when using ASR and Hyper-V replication between a Hyper-V sites and Azure.

trans-unit.source: The most current list of supported guest operating systems is available in the article titled <linkText>About Virtual Machines and Guest Operating Systems</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The most current list of supported guest operating systems is available in the article titled <linkText>About Virtual Machines and Guest Operating Systems</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: No, this type of chained replication isn't supported
trans-unit.target: No, this type of chained replication isn't supported

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: While configuring protection between VMM clouds in ASR specify the authentication type.
trans-unit.target: While configuring protection between VMM clouds in ASR specify the authentication type.

trans-unit.source: Select HTTPS unless you have a working Kerberos environment configured.
trans-unit.target: Select HTTPS unless you have a working Kerberos environment configured.

trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery will automatically configure certificates for HTTPS authentication.
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery will automatically configure certificates for HTTPS authentication.

trans-unit.source: No manual configuration is required.
trans-unit.target: No manual configuration is required.

trans-unit.source: If you do select Kerberos, a Kerberos ticket will be used for mutual authentication of the host servers.
trans-unit.target: If you do select Kerberos, a Kerberos ticket will be used for mutual authentication of the host servers.

trans-unit.source: By default, port 8083 (for Kerberos) and 8084 (for certificates) will be opened in the Windows Firewall on the Hyper-V host servers.
trans-unit.target: By default, port 8083 (for Kerberos) and 8084 (for certificates) will be opened in the Windows Firewall on the Hyper-V host servers.

trans-unit.source: Note that this setting is only relevant for Hyper-V host servers running on Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: Note that this setting is only relevant for Hyper-V host servers running on Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: No problem.
trans-unit.target: No problem.

trans-unit.source: ASR supports the scenario where replication may already be set up, in which case, you can leverage ASR for virtual machine-centric disaster recovery orchestration, configuration of disaster recovery networking, application-aware recovery plans, disaster recovery drills, and your compliance and audit reporting requirements.
trans-unit.target: ASR supports the scenario where replication may already be set up, in which case, you can leverage ASR for virtual machine-centric disaster recovery orchestration, configuration of disaster recovery networking, application-aware recovery plans, disaster recovery drills, and your compliance and audit reporting requirements.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: We need the SAN array to be brought under management by VMM using an array-specific SMI-S provider.
trans-unit.target: We need the SAN array to be brought under management by VMM using an array-specific SMI-S provider.

trans-unit.source: We support single VMM HA deployments based on the array type, though the recommended configuration is to use separate VMM servers to manage the sites.
trans-unit.target: We support single VMM HA deployments based on the array type, though the recommended configuration is to use separate VMM servers to manage the sites.

trans-unit.source: NetApp, EMC and HP have enabled support for Azure Site Recovery SAN replication with updates to their SMI-S providers.
trans-unit.target: NetApp, EMC and HP have enabled support for Azure Site Recovery SAN replication with updates to their SMI-S providers.

trans-unit.source: For more details see below links.
trans-unit.target: For more details see below links.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NetApp Clustered Data ONTAP 8.2</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NetApp Clustered Data ONTAP 8.2</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>EMC VMAX series</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>EMC VMAX series</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HP 3PAR</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HP 3PAR</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: We work with existing replication set up by your storage administrator, which means that the storage administrator does not need to make any changes on their arrays.
trans-unit.target: We work with existing replication set up by your storage administrator, which means that the storage administrator does not need to make any changes on their arrays.

trans-unit.source: However, organizations that want to automate their storage management through SCVMM can also provision storage using ASR and VMM.
trans-unit.target: However, organizations that want to automate their storage management through SCVMM can also provision storage using ASR and VMM.

trans-unit.source: Yes, yes, and yes!
trans-unit.target: Yes, yes, and yes!

trans-unit.source: When using (SAN) array-based replication to enable replication and protection between Hyper-V Sites, all you need is the ASR DR Provider to be installed on the SCVMM Server(s).
trans-unit.target: When using (SAN) array-based replication to enable replication and protection between Hyper-V Sites, all you need is the ASR DR Provider to be installed on the SCVMM Server(s).

trans-unit.source: Remember that this is also the only host that needs connectivity to the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Remember that this is also the only host that needs connectivity to the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Your arrays also need to be discovered by SCVMM using an updated SMI-S provider that is made available by your respective storage vendors.
trans-unit.target: Your arrays also need to be discovered by SCVMM using an updated SMI-S provider that is made available by your respective storage vendors.

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can replicate a physical server using ASR and run it as VM in Azure in the event that your on-premises server goes down.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can replicate a physical server using ASR and run it as VM in Azure in the event that your on-premises server goes down.

trans-unit.source: Failback to an on-premises physical server isn't currently supported.
trans-unit.target: Failback to an on-premises physical server isn't currently supported.

trans-unit.source: You can fail back to a virtual machine running on Hyper-V or VMware.
trans-unit.target: You can fail back to a virtual machine running on Hyper-V or VMware.

trans-unit.source: While Azure is designed for service resilience, we like to plan for the worst.
trans-unit.target: While Azure is designed for service resilience, we like to plan for the worst.

trans-unit.source: ASR is already engineered for failover to a secondary Azure datacenter in accordance with the Azure SLA.
trans-unit.target: ASR is already engineered for failover to a secondary Azure datacenter in accordance with the Azure SLA.

trans-unit.source: We also ensure that even when this happens, your metadata and ASR Vault remain within the same geographic region in which you chose to your vault.
trans-unit.target: We also ensure that even when this happens, your metadata and ASR Vault remain within the same geographic region in which you chose to your vault.

trans-unit.source: You can use the ASR portal to perform an unplanned failover with a single click.
trans-unit.target: You can use the ASR portal to perform an unplanned failover with a single click.

trans-unit.source: No connectivity from your primary datacenter is needed to perform the failover.
trans-unit.target: No connectivity from your primary datacenter is needed to perform the failover.

trans-unit.source: It's likely that applications that need to be running in your secondary datacenter after a failover will need some form of Internet connectivity.
trans-unit.target: It's likely that applications that need to be running in your secondary datacenter after a failover will need some form of Internet connectivity.

trans-unit.source: ASR assumes that even though the primary site and ISP may be impacted during a disaster, the secondary site’s SCVMM server is still connected to ASR.
trans-unit.target: ASR assumes that even though the primary site and ISP may be impacted during a disaster, the secondary site’s SCVMM server is still connected to ASR.

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Failing back from Azure back to your on-premises site is simple using the one-click process through the ASR portal.
trans-unit.target: Failing back from Azure back to your on-premises site is simple using the one-click process through the ASR portal.

trans-unit.source: There's no automatic failover option.
trans-unit.target: There's no automatic failover option.

trans-unit.source: You can either hit a single button in the portal to trigger a failover, or you can use <linkText>Site Recovery PowerShell</linkText><title></title> to trigger a failover.
trans-unit.target: You can either hit a single button in the portal to trigger a failover, or you can use <linkText>Site Recovery PowerShell</linkText><title></title> to trigger a failover.

trans-unit.source: You use on-premises Orchestrator or Operations Manager to witness a virtual machine failure and then decide to trigger the failover using the SDK.
trans-unit.target: You use on-premises Orchestrator or Operations Manager to witness a virtual machine failure and then decide to trigger the failover using the SDK.

trans-unit.source: This makes it an automatic process.
trans-unit.target: This makes it an automatic process.

trans-unit.source: You can subscribe to email alerts directly from the ASR service to be notified about any issues that need attention.
trans-unit.target: You can subscribe to email alerts directly from the ASR service to be notified about any issues that need attention.

trans-unit.source: You can also monitor ongoing replication health using SCOM.
trans-unit.target: You can also monitor ongoing replication health using SCOM.

trans-unit.source: To start deploying ASR:
trans-unit.target: To start deploying ASR:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up protection between an on-premises VMM site and Azure</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up protection between an on-premises VMM site and Azure</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up protection between an on-premises Hyper-V site and Azure</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up protection between an on-premises Hyper-V site and Azure</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up protection between two on-premises VMM sites</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up protection between two on-premises VMM sites</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up protection between two on-premises VMM sites with SAN</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up protection between two on-premises VMM sites with SAN</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up protection with a single VMM server</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up protection with a single VMM server</linkText><title></title>
